description: From Middle English, borrowed from Old French conclusion, from Latin conclūsiō, from the past participle stem of conclūdere (“to conclude”), from con- +‎ claudō, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *kleh₂u- (“key, hook, nail”).

entries.meaning: The end, finish, close or last part of something.
The outcome or result of a process or act.
A decision reached after careful thought.
examples: The board has come to the conclusion that the proposed takeover would not be in the interest of our shareholders.

entries.meaning: (logic) In an argument or syllogism, the proposition that follows as a necessary consequence of the premises.
(obsolete) An experiment, or something from which a conclusion may be drawn.
(law) The end or close of a pleading, for example, the formal ending of an indictment, "against the peace", etc.
(law) An estoppel or bar by which a person is held to a particular position.
